channel.title: matt lebrun
channel.description: in between code, coffee, and peanut butter.

item.title: logging projects and experiments
item.description:
Several things happened last year relating to our smartphones breaking down and with it, my attempts to repair and/or replace them altogether.

Those repair (and destruction) attempts rekindled my interest in hardware tinkering, making a pact to only buy used older generation flagship phones, and preferring hardware you can …
item.dc:creator: Matt Lebrun

item.title: value and cost
item.description:
Think about cost as an economical construct. An objective means of measuring the amount of something for trade.

Likewise, think about value as a subjective and personal measurement of how important something is to you.

Trust and time are some of those currencies that people highly value.

To regain or …
item.dc:creator: Matt Lebrun

item.title: how to answer questions you don't know the answer to
item.description:
Lately, I find myself reflecting on this question:

How do you answer a question that you don't know the answer to?

This must be a situation that a lot of people in the training / teaching services find themselves in for the better part of their careers.

The truth is, you …

item.title: kivy development environment setup
item.description:
I've been itching to get back to (re)learning Kivy again by creating games with it.

With any development endeavor, the environment needs some setting up. It's really been a while since I've used Kivy so I'm documenting my process with this post.

pre-requisites

item.title: on principles and thinking clearly
item.description:
I chanced upon an article from thepolymathproject.com about "A few Principles in Thinking Clearly".

I learned about Czech-Canadian polymath, Vaclav Smil and his perspective on thinking clearly. He's apparently widely read by none other that Bill Gates himself. Gates even says, "I learn more by reading Vaclav Smith that …
item.dc:creator: Matt Lebrun

item.title: getting into cycling
item.description: If you're like me, you probably had your on-and-off bouts using a bicycle. Perhaps you even thought it's not meant for you. However, life changes, Manila traffic got worst, and I wanted to break away from being sedentary. So here I am with a renewed interest in using a bicycle …

item.title: pycon experiments: getting people talking
item.description: A few months before PyConPH 2018, I chanced upon Eric Holscher's blog post on Breaking Cliques at Events, specifically in difficulty in meeting new people. This striked me as a very important point as I personally relate to the idea that as an introvert, I find it difficult talking to …
item.dc:creator: Matt Lebrun

item.title: technology as a path to heaven
item.description:
Think of a promised place where there is no pain, hunger, sickness, and suffering. Where life is abundant and happiness is everlasting. It could be a utopian place, or state of mind or being.

Imagine having the ability to create this world or state ourselves and making it accessible to …

item.title: blog refresh 2017
item.description:
Starting over this blog has been one of those things I've been itching to do but never got to because #life-happens.

item.description:
If you have been using HackerRank and encountered problems that accepts an indefinite amount of input from STDIN like this:

item.title: use different git ssh key per project
item.description:
If you happen to be using different git accounts with they're own SSH keys; i.e. you use different keys for deployment, personal, company A, company B, etc.

Then you probably have wondered how to tell git which key to use to manage the repo.

You could use the git-remote-ext …

item.title: a box of chocolates
item.description:

I'm a curious guy. I look a the world with an eye of wonder. When I'm interested in something -- may it be a game, a skill, a piece of technology …

item.title: 4 weeks to fitness experiment
item.description:
A healthy programmer, is an effective programmer.
- me (when deciding to write this post)

One of my key goals for this year is to get in to the habit of keeping myself healthy. I believe its in our best interest as software engineers to have a balanced lifestlye to ensure …

item.title: a gaming blog
item.description:

item.title: good habits: the root cause in turning your dreams into reality
item.description:
I attended a dream boarding workshop with Mickey last September 22. What I thought to be just a day of fulfilling "boyfriend duties", turned out quite amazing.

I made a realization.

In case you didn't know; dream boarding is when you put visual representation of your goals, desires, ambitions, dreams …
item.dc:creator: Matt Lebrun

item.title: why you don't need to know everything right away
item.description:
Learning and researching about a new technology or problem area is a very exciting activity for programmers.

Curiosity, for a programmer, is like an insatiable impulse. An unquenchable thirst. You take your time as you browse through one information to another. Consuming content after content. This can span from hours …
item.dc:creator: Matt Lebrun

item.title: hello world! v2.0: reflections on leaving the 9-5 life
item.description:
My recent move to finally join (full-time) the tech start-up scene made me reflect once again on this topic.

I feel like I've just stepped into the "unknown abyss" that we call the entrepreneurial road where a steady monthly paycheck is out of the question. This is quite a big …

item.title: don't waste time, it's more scarce than you think!
item.description:
When you say "yes" to others, make sure you are not saying "no" to yourself. - Paulo Coelho
